children: A 35-year-old man is evaluated for exertional dyspnea and a sensation of pounding in the neck that has progressed over the last year. Blood pressure is 150/60 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 60/min.
(We recommend listening to
this clip

with headphones or external speakers rather than internal computer or mobile phone speakers. It may be helpful to maximize the volume setting of the listening device. In the videos, a cotton swab is placed on the carotid artery to help identify the timing of cardiac sounds and murmurs and, in some cases, to provide a visual representation of the carotid artery configuration.)
Which of the following best describes the murmur at the mid-left sternal edge?
This patient has the characteristic high-pitched, long, blowing diastolic decrescendo murmur of chronic aortic regurgitation. This murmur begins immediately after S
and is best heard at the mid-left sternal edge. In this example, the S

is nearly inaudible because it is obscured by the loud murmur. In some patients, the murmur of aortic regurgitation is much softer and can be heard only with the patient seated, leaning forward, and holding the breath at end-expiration. The presence of a wide pulse pressure is also typical of chronic aortic regurgitation.

Aortic stenosis is a systolic murmur. The murmur of tricuspid regurgitation is also heard during systole, and the intensity may increase with inspiration. Mitral stenosis produces a low-frequency diastolic murmur heard best at the cardiac apex.

objective.__html: Diagnose aortic regurgitation on auscultation.

children: A patient evaluated for cough is found to have an enlarged cardiac silhouette on chest radiography. He is suspected of having pericardial effusion. Ultrasonography is performed with the probe placed in the subxiphoid area.
(Note that there is no sound for
this video
Which of the following is the most likely interpretation of this study?
This patient's ultrasound
shows
a large, circumferential pericardial effusion (
arrows

) with evidence of cardiac tamponade. An anechoic space is seen between the liver in the near field and the myocardium of the heart and also surrounds the entire heart, indicating a large effusion. Cardiac tamponade is typically seen as collapse of the right atrium or the right ventricle during the diastolic phase of the cardiac cycle. In this study, although the right ventricular free wall appears to “wiggle,” this is caused by inward diastolic movement typical in tamponade.

objective.__html: Diagnose pericardial effusion using point-of-care ultrasonography.

children: A 63-year-old woman is admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following abnormalities is demonstrated on this patient's ECG?

The ECG shows multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT). MAT is most commonly seen in acutely ill patients, most often in the setting of pulmonary disease, such as an exacerbation of COPD with associated hypoxia and electrolyte abnormalities. The ECG in MAT is defined by the presence of discrete P waves with at least three different morphologic patterns and varying P-P, P-R, and R-R intervals, as
shown
. The morphologic features of P waves are generally best seen in leads II, III, and V

. The rate is greater than 100 beats per minute, distinguishing MAT from wandering atrial pacemaker. The rhythm is irregular; however, unlike in atrial fibrillation, P waves are detectable, and there is a 1:1 relationship of each P wave to a QRS complex. Therapy is directed at the underlying disease process because without treatment of the underlying cause, the arrhythmia is often refractory to therapy or may recur.

objective.__html: Identify multifocal atrial tachycardia on ECG.

children: A 61-year-old man is evaluated following the recent diagnosis of hypertension.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following abnormalities is seen on this patient's ECG?

This ECG demonstrates left bundle branch block. Left bundle branch block is characterized by the following features: (1) QRS widening of at least 120 ms, (2) upright monophasic QRS complex in leads I and V
(the QRS complex may also be notched), and (3) a predominantly negative QRS complex in lead V

. In the ECG shown, all three features are evident. In both left and right bundle branch block, the ST-T–wave pattern is inscribed in the opposite direction of the main QRS vectors; these ST-T–wave abnormalities are secondary to the bundle branch block and do not indicate additional underlying pathology.

objective.__html: Identify ECG features of left bundle branch block.

children: A 19-year-old man with substance use disorder is evaluated for 3 weeks of fever and malaise and a new heart murmur.
Funduscopic findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is infective endocarditis. This funduscopic image
shows
Roth spots with a white/paler center (
arrows
). These hemorrhagic lesions of the retina are associated with infective endocarditis and certain leukemias.

objective.__html: Identify Roth spots associated with infective endocarditis.

children: A 69-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for a 1-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and bendopnea. Vital signs are normal. Focused point-of-care cardiac ultrasonography is performed.
(Note that there is no sound for
this video
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

text.__html: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction

children: This patient's left ventricular function is severely reduced. The ultrasound
shows

a parasternal long-axis view of the left ventricle. The chamber of the left ventricle is abnormally large and round, and its size decreases minimally during systole. Although the posterior wall appears to thicken during systole, the interventricular septum does not. Additionally, the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve is quite far from the interventricular septum when opening during diastole. By using the markers on the right of the screen, the distance between the anterior leaflet and the interventricular septum can be approximated to be more than 1 cm, which is considered the upper limit of normal for this measurement. Together, these findings strongly suggest severely reduced left ventricular function. There is no pericardial effusion to suggest cardiac tamponade and the aortic and mitral valves show no signs of significant restriction of leaflet opening (AV = aortic valve; IVS = interventricular septum; LA = left atrium; LV = left ventricle; MV = mitral valve).

objective.__html: Evaluate left ventricular function with point-of-care ultrasonography.

children: A 58-year-old woman is evaluated prior to an elective total hip arthroplasty.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following abnormalities is seen on this patient's ECG?

This ECG shows evidence of a nonacute inferior myocardial infarction, with Q waves in leads II, III, and aVF and without ST-segment changes. Additionally, it demonstrates a nonacute posterior myocardial infarction (or posterior extension of the inferior infarction) with increased R-wave amplitude and duration (R>S), without ST-segment changes in the anterior precordial leads V
through V
There are no ECG changes consistent with an anterior or lateral infarction.

objective.__html: Identify a nonacute inferior myocardial infarction on ECG.

children: A 59-year-old man is evaluated following a transient ischemic attack.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following abnormalities is demonstrated on this patient's ECG?

This ECG is characteristic of atrial fibrillation, with an irregularly irregular rhythm and no discernible P waves. Atrial fibrillation can present with a rapid ventricular response, with an average rate of more than 110/min; a controlled ventricular response, with an average rate between 60/min and 110/min; or a slow ventricular response, with an average rate of less than 60/min. This patient's ECG tracing shows an average rate of approximately 75/min.

objective.__html: Identify atrial fibrillation on ECG.

children: A 44-year-old man with a newly diagnosed ischemic stroke is evaluated in the emergency department.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following abnormalities is seen on this patient's ECG?
This ECG demonstrates features of left ventricular hypertrophy, including both of the Sokolow-Lyon electrocardiographic criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy:
The sum of the deepest S wave in lead V
or V
and the tallest R wave in lead V
or V
is 35 mm or greater;
or
The R wave in lead aVL is 11 mm or greater.
Alternatively, if the deepest S wave plus the S wave in lead V

sums to 23 mm or greater for women or 28 mm or greater for men, this finding has been found to be more sensitive than the traditional electrocardiographic criteria for diagnosis of left ventricular hypertrophy, with preserved specificity.
Secondary ST-T wave abnormalities (asymmetric ST-segment depression and T-wave inversion) is another indication of left ventricular hypertrophy and are seen in leads I, aVL, and V
through V
in this tracing.

objective.__html: Identify ECG features of left ventricular hypertrophy.

children: A 50-year-old woman is evaluated for palpitations.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following abnormalities is demonstrated on this patient's ECG?

This ECG demonstrates atrial flutter, which is characterized by a regular atrial rate that is often close to 300/min and by a sawtooth pattern. Flutter waves are most easily seen in the inferior leads (II, III, and aVF) and lead V

. Most commonly, there is 2:1 conduction to the ventricles, resulting in a ventricular rate of approximately 150/min, as seen in the first part of this tracing. A 4:1 conduction pattern with a rate of 75/min is also seen.

objective.__html: Identify atrial flutter on ECG.

children: A 50-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-day history of fever, malaise, and heart murmur. Today, crops of
nonpainful cutaneous lesions
have appeared on his feet.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Infective endocarditis is most likely associated with the skin findings shown. Janeway lesions are nonpainful, macular (occasionally nodular), blanching lesions located on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet; they are associated with infective endocarditis.

objective.__html: Diagnose Janeway lesions and recognize their association with infective endocarditis.

children: A 49-year-old man is evaluated for symptoms of dyspnea, peripheral edema, and exercise intolerance. Echocardiography shows biventricular increased wall thickness.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is an infiltrative cardiomyopathy, such as cardiac amyloidosis. This ECG demonstrates low voltage with QRS amplitude of less than 5 mm in the limb leads. Low voltage may also be demonstrated by a QRS amplitude of less than 10 mm in the precordial leads. When low ECG voltage accompanies increased wall thickness on echocardiogram, an infiltrative cardiomyopathy, such as amyloidosis, should be considered. Serum protein electrophoresis/urine protein electrophoresis and free light-chain analysis may help identify immunoglobulin light-chain amyloidosis.

objective.__html: Diagnose myocardial disease with restrictive physiology.

children: A 30-year-old man is evaluated for exertional dyspnea. On physical examination, a parasternal impulse is noted at the left sternal border. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard at the second left intercostal space with fixed splitting of the S
ECG is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is ostium secundum atrial septal defect (ASD). This ECG demonstrates the typical findings associated with an ostium secundum ASD, including right axis deviation (negative QRS in lead I with positive QRS in leads II, III, and aVF) and incomplete right bundle branch block (QRS duration <120 ms, prominent S wave in lateral leads, and prominent qR in V1). ASDs are generally classified by their location. Ostium secundum ASDs, the most common type of ASD (75% of cases), are located in the mid portion of the atrial septum and are usually isolated anomalies. Symptoms may include fatigue, exertional dyspnea, arrhythmias, and paradoxical embolism. Clinical findings in patients with an ASD include a parasternal impulse, fixed splitting of the S
, and a pulmonary outflow murmur. A diastolic flow rumble across the tricuspid valve can occur with a large left-to-right shunt.

objective.__html: Identify ECG findings associated with ostium secundum atrial septal defect.

children: A 68-year-old woman is evaluated for exertional dyspnea. She was previously asymptomatic, but 4 months ago she began having shortness of breath during moderate activity. Blood pressure is 132/80 mm Hg, pulse rate is 80/min, and respiration rate is 22/min. Auscultation is performed at the upper right sternal border.
(We recommend listening to
this clip

with headphones or external speakers rather than internal computer or mobile phone speakers. It may be helpful to maximize the volume setting of the listening device. In the videos, a cotton swab is placed on the carotid artery to help identify the timing of cardiac sounds and murmurs and, in some cases, to provide a visual representation of the carotid artery configuration.)
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is aortic stenosis. Auscultation reveals a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur at the upper right sternal edge compatible with aortic stenosis. The murmur begins early in systole and extends nearly to S
. The associated carotid pulsation, visually represented by the cotton swab on the carotid artery, may be small in volume and delayed (pulsation occurring slightly after S

Mitral regurgitation produces a higher-pitched, holosystolic murmur that is loudest at the apex. The murmur of pulmonic stenosis is heard best at the left upper sternal border and may increase in intensity with inspiration. A small ventricular septal defect without pulmonary hypertension presents with a loud and often palpable holosystolic murmur located at the left sternal border that may obliterate the S
. Progressive pulmonary hypertension results in shortening of the murmur.

objective.__html: Diagnose aortic stenosis on auscultation.

children: A 46-year-old woman is evaluated for atypical chest pain.
Exercise stress testing
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Although the resting ECG is normal, the exercise ECG demonstrates horizontal ST depressions in multiple leads, including II, III, aVF, and V
through V

. The most likely cause of the ST depressions following exercise is ischemic coronary artery disease. Ischemia is defined by the development of horizontal or downsloping ST-segment depression of at least 1 mm occurring 80 ms after the J point on exercise ECG. Unlike ST segment changes in the setting of acute coronary syndrome, ST-segment depression on exercise testing cannot localize ischemia.

objective.__html: Diagnose cardiac ischemia based on exercise stress testing.

children: A 42-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for an 8-hour history of acute-onset, sharp, and persistent chest pain. Blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 60/min. Auscultation is performed with the diaphragm at the left sternal border.
(We recommend listening to
this clip

with headphones or external speakers rather than internal computer or mobile phone speakers. It may be helpful to maximize the volume setting of the listening device. In the videos, a cotton swab is placed on the carotid artery to help identify the timing of cardiac sounds and murmurs and, in some cases, to provide a visual representation of the carotid artery configuration.)
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The predominant sign of pericarditis is a pericardial friction rub, typically triphasic but possibly present in only one or two phases of the cardiac cycle. Often described as creaking, grating, or scratching, pericardial friction rubs are heard best at the left sternal border with the patient sitting up, leaning forward, and holding the breath in expiration. As in this example, pericardial rubs may vary in intensity with respiration.

Aortic regurgitation is a high-pitched diastolic murmur heard best along the mid-left upper sternal border. The murmur of aortic stenosis is a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur loudest at the upper right sternal edge. A continuous murmur of patent ductus arteriosus begins in systole and extends without interruption into diastole.

objective.__html: Identify pericardial rub on auscultation.

children: A 43-year-old man is evaluated for nonanginal chest pain.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following is shown on this patient's ECG?
This ECG demonstrates right bundle branch block. ECG features of right bundle branch block include QRS widening (≥120 ms), an rSR' or rsR' pattern in lead V
, and a wide terminal S wave in leads I and V

. Several premature atrial contractions are also seen. In both left and right bundle branch block, the ST-T wave pattern is inscribed in the opposite direction of the main QRS vectors; these ST-T wave abnormalities are secondary to the bundle branch block and do not indicate additional underlying pathology.

objective.__html: Identify ECG features of right bundle branch block.

children: A 66-year-old man is evaluated for sudden-onset dyspnea. Blood pressure is 198/120 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals aortic regurgitation and pulmonary crackles. Emergency
chest CT
with contrast is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is type A aortic dissection. The CT scan with contrast
shows
a dissection plane extending through the aortic arch (
arrow

). Type A aortic dissection classically presents with the sudden onset of chest or back pain that has a tearing or ripping quality; however, not all patients will have this symptom. Patients may present with hypertension, syncope, a murmur of aortic regurgitation, or heart failure in the setting of sudden aortic insufficiency. The findings of asymmetric blood pressures in the upper extremities, asymmetric pulses, or pulsus paradoxus should all raise suspicion for acute aortic dissection.

objective.__html: Diagnose type A aortic dissection.

children: A 40-year-old woman is evaluated for hypotension. Blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 110/min. Heart sounds are distant. Jugular venous pressure is elevated.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is cardiac tamponade. This ECG demonstrates electrical alternans, a shifting of the QRS axis with each beat related to a swinging motion of the heart within the pericardial fluid. It is most clearly seen in this tracing in lead I and the precordial leads. Electrical alternans and low voltage (not seen on this ECG) are suggestive of cardiac tamponade. Clinical signs of tamponade include tachycardia, hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and elevation of the jugular venous pulse. The
y

descent of the jugular venous pulse may be absent because passive filling of the ventricles is impeded by the intrapericardial pressure. The cardiac silhouette is also typically enlarged on chest radiograph if the accumulation of fluid has occurred slowly.

objective.__html: Diagnose cardiac tamponade.

children: A 35-year-old man is evaluated for the acute onset of severe chest pain.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is pericarditis. Electrocardiographic changes characteristic of acute pericarditis include diffuse ST-segment elevations and a depressed PR interval, both of which are present in this patient's ECG; leads I and II in this ECG demonstrate a depressed PR interval, most notably in the lead II rhythm strip. As pericarditis evolves, the electrocardiographic manifestations change and are classified into stages: Stage 1 is characterized by diffuse ST-segment elevations; stage 2, by “pseudonormalization,” in which the ST segments normalize; stage 3, by diffuse T-wave inversion and possible slightly depressed ST segments; and stage 4, by a return to normal on ECG.

objective.__html: Identify manifestations of pericarditis on ECG.

children: A 30-year-old man is evaluated for hypertension. He is asymptomatic. A systolic murmur is heard in the left infraclavicular region. Blood pressure is 168/90 mm Hg in both arms.
Chest radiograph is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
This patient most likely has aortic coarctation, as suggested by the
radiographic finding
of an indentation at the coarctation site (
black arrow
), resulting in a “figure 3 sign” caused by dilatation of the aorta above (
blue arrow
) and below (
red arrow
) the area of coarctation. This frontal chest radiograph also demonstrates “notching” of the inferior borders of several ribs (
yellow circles
). Rib notching is caused by erosion of the rib by forceful pulsations of dilated intercostal arteries involved in collateral blood flow.

objective.__html: Recognize signs of aortic coarctation on a chest radiograph.

children: A 25-year-old man is evaluated for palpations and lightheadedness.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This ECG demonstrates atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT). AVNRT accounts for two thirds of all supraventricular tachycardias. Patients with AVNRT have two electrical conduction pathways that are proximal to or within the atrioventricular node. One pathway conducts the electrical impulse rapidly but has a prolonged refractory period (fast pathway), and the second has slower conduction but a short refractory period (slow pathway). During sinus conduction, the impulse travels down both pathways; however, electrical conduction down the slow pathway is blocked at or below the level of the atrioventricular node because of the “refractory wave” produced by the previous electrical conduction down the fast pathway. If a premature beat is correctly timed, the conduction can travel down the slow pathway to activate the ventricles and retrograde up the fast pathway to activate the atria, thus creating a circuit and a sustained tachycardia with a ventricular rate between 120/min and 220/min. In the most common variety of AVNRT, the P wave is buried in the QRS complex or a portion of the P wave can be discerned, altering the morphology of the QRS complex. In the accompanying ECG, the P waves are hidden within the QRS complex, indicating AVNRT. In both atrial tachycardia and sinus tachycardia, P waves are visible; in antidromic atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia, the QRS complex is wide owing to impulse conduction over the bypass tract and outside the normal conduction system in the ventricles.

objective.__html: Identify atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia on ECG.

children: A 49-year-old man undergoes
ECG
following reperfusion therapy for an acute myocardial infarction.
Which of the following abnormalities is demonstrated on this patient's ECG?

This ECG demonstrates an accelerated idioventricular rhythm, which is an escape rhythm arising from the ventricular myocardium. The QRS complexes are wide (as in all ventricular arrhythmias) and fairly regular. An idioventricular rhythm is typically at a rate between 30/min and 40/min but is considered accelerated when the rate is more than 50/min but less than 100/min; the heart rate on this tracing is approximately 90/min. Accelerated idioventricular rhythm, which commonly arises after reperfusion, is generally benign and transient. The slow rate is a major difference between accelerated idioventricular rhythm and ventricular tachycardia.

objective.__html: Identify an accelerated idioventricular rhythm on ECG.

children: A 73-year-old woman with extensive cardiovascular disease and poorly controlled hypertension is evaluated for acute-onset ripping chest pain that radiates to her back.
Chest radiograph is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is acute aortic dissection. This patient's chest radiograph shows a widened superior mediastinum and a right pleural effusion consistent with aortic dissection, although these findings are not diagnostic. The diagnosis of aortic dissection can be established with transesophageal echocardiography, CT angiography, or MR angiography, all of which have similar sensitivity and specificity for acute thoracic aortic disease. Because of its wide availability and short image acquisition time, CT angiography has become the primary diagnostic test for acute thoracic aortic disease.

objective.__html: Diagnose acute aortic dissection based on chest radiography.

children: A 68-year-old woman is evaluated for progressive exertional dyspnea. Focused point-of-care cardiac ultrasonography is performed.
(Note that there is no sound for
this video
Which of the following is the most appropriate interpretation of this patient's left ventricular function?

This patient's left ventricular function is normal. The ultrasound shows a parasternal long-axis view of the left ventricle. The wall thickness and chamber size of the left ventricle appear normal and shrink appropriately during systole. The interventricular septum and posterior wall thicken and move inward during systole, which is normal. The movement of the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve and its distance from the interventricular septum during diastole can also be used as a rough gauge of left ventricular systolic function, with a distance of less than 1.0 cm generally considered normal. Although this distance may be measured on a frozen image, it is often estimated in point-of-care studies using the scale on the right of the screen as a reference. As
shown
, the anterior leaflet appears to slap against the interventricular septum during diastole (
red circle

). The chamber size, wall motion, and mitral valve movement findings all strongly suggest normal left ventricular function. (AV = aortic valve; IVS = interventricular septum; LA = left atrium; LV = left ventricle; MV = mitral valve)

objective.__html: Evaluate left ventricular function with point-of-care ultrasonography.

children: A 56-year-old man is evaluated for bradycardia prior to cataract surgery. He is asymptomatic.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following ECG findings is present?

Sinus bradycardia (sinus rhythm with a heart rate <60/min) may be appropriate in several situations, including in trained athletes or during sleep, when the heart rate may fall as low as 30/min. This patient's heart rate is approximately 47/min. A premature atrial contraction is also seen.

objective.__html: Identify sinus bradycardia on ECG.

children: A 70-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for acute worsening of dyspnea.
Chest radiograph is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient's chest radiograph shows cardiomegaly and bilateral perihilar alveolar infiltrates, consistent with a diagnosis of pulmonary edema due to heart failure. A small left pleural effusion is seen, as well as fluid in the minor fissure, also consistent with heart failure. Although cardiomegaly can be seen in tamponade, diffuse alveolar infiltrates are not a feature of this diagnosis.

objective.__html: Diagnose pulmonary edema on chest radiography.

children: A 58-year-old man is evaluated for right leg tiredness and cramping when walking 25 yards. His feet are shown following elevation
top
and during dependent positioning
bottom
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is peripheral artery disease involving the right extremity. The patient has right foot pallor with elevation and dependent rubor. Previously known as the Buerger test, the patient's foot color is observed when it is elevated and again when it is dependent. The likelihood ratio of a positive finding (elevation pallor and dependent rubor) in the symptomatic extremity is 2.8 for peripheral artery disease.

objective.__html: Diagnose peripheral artery disease.

children: A 28-year-old man is evaluated during a routine examination. Blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 60/min. Auscultation is performed with firm pressure on the diaphragm at the upper left sternal border.
(We recommend listening to
this clip

with headphones or external speakers rather than internal computer or mobile phone speakers. It may be helpful to maximize the volume setting of the listening device. In the videos, a cotton swab is placed on the carotid artery to help identify the timing of cardiac sounds and murmurs and, in some cases, to provide a visual representation of the carotid artery configuration.)
Which of the following best describes the second sound?
In this patient, auscultation reveals normal splitting of S
during inspiration. Both components of a split S
are high-frequency sounds heard best with the diaphragm in the second left intercostal space.
Splitting of S
represents asynchronous closure of the aortic and pulmonic valves. In the normal adult, splitting varies with the respiratory cycle and is perceived as a single S
during expiration and a double S
during inspiration.

objective.__html: Identify physiologic splitting of S<sub>2</sub> on auscultation.

children: A 30-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-week history of fever and malaise.
Nail findings are
shown
Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?

Infective endocarditis is most likely associated with this patient's nail findings. Splinter hemorrhages are subungual linear pigmented streaks following the long axis of the nail; most are located at the distal one third of the nail. Their color changes from purple to brown or black as they age. Trauma is the most common cause of splinter hemorrhages. Other causes include infective endocarditis, arterial emboli, trichinosis, scurvy, and dermatologic diseases, such as psoriasis.

objective.__html: Identify splinter hemorrhages and recognize their association with infective endocarditis.

children: A 47-year-old woman with sarcoidosis is evaluated for an irregular pulse, a sensation of pounding in the neck, and an episode of syncope.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This ECG shows ventricular tachycardia, which is typically caused by organic heart disease. It begins approximately one third of the way into the tracing and is marked by an abrupt change in axis and widening of the QRS complex. Ventricular tachycardia is characterized by fairly regular wide QRS complexes, a pulse rate of more than 120/min, and atrioventricular dissociation. Ventricular tachycardia can be characterized as either sustained (lasting >30 seconds) or nonsustained, and as monomorphic, if all of the QRS complexes have the same morphology, or as polymorphic, if the QRS pattern twists across the baseline (e.g., torsades de pointes). Ventricular tachycardia can degenerate into ventricular fibrillation.

objective.__html: Identify ventricular tachycardia on ECG.

children: A 34-year-old woman is evaluated for unexplained right heart enlargement and a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Physical examination reveals a parasternal impulse, fixed splitting of S
, mitral regurgitation, and a pulmonary outflow murmur.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is ostium primum atrial septal defect (ASD). This ECG demonstrates the typical findings in ostium primum ASD, including left axis deviation, first-degree atrioventricular block, and right bundle branch block. Located in the lowest portion of the atrial septum, ostium primum ASD (15%-20% of ASDs) are a component of endocardial cushion defects. Associated abnormalities include mitral valve, ventricular septum, and subaortic anomalies. Clinical findings in patients with an ASD include a parasternal impulse, fixed splitting of the S
, and a pulmonary outflow murmur. A diastolic flow rumble across the tricuspid valve can occur with a large left-to-right shunt.

objective.__html: Identify ECG findings of ostium primum atrial septal defect.

children: A 45-year-old woman is evaluated for an 18-month history of progressive fatigue and dyspnea. Blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg, pulse rate is 76/min, and respiration rate is normal. The apical impulse is slightly sustained but not displaced. Auscultation is performed at the cardiac apex.
(We recommend listening to
this clip

with headphones or external speakers rather than internal computer or mobile phone speakers. It may be helpful to maximize the volume setting of the listening device. In the videos, a cotton swab is placed on the carotid artery to help identify the timing of cardiac sounds and murmurs and, in some cases, to provide a visual representation of the carotid artery configuration.)
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient has the typical findings of mitral stenosis, including a diastolic opening snap followed by a long, low-frequency diastolic murmur best heard at the apex. The murmur peaks during mid-diastole and again before a loud S
. The murmur of mitral stenosis is best appreciated by auscultating with the bell of the stethoscope with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position.

Aortic regurgitation produces a high-pitched diastolic murmur heard best along the mid left sternal border. Mitral regurgitation produces a high-pitched holosystolic murmur loudest at the cardiac apex. The murmur of pulmonic regurgitation is early diastolic, best heard over the left second and third interspaces and increases in intensity with inspiration.

objective.__html: Diagnose mitral stenosis on auscultation.

children: A 64-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department following an episode of syncope.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following abnormalities is demonstrated on this patient's ECG?
The ECG
shown

demonstrates a junctional rhythm, or atrioventricular nodal rhythm. Junctional rhythms are regular supraventricular rhythms in which the P wave in lead II is negative (preceding or following the QRS complex) or absent (
arrows

). An atrioventricular nodal escape rhythm occurs when the junctional rate is between 40/min and 60/min and the sinoatrial node is delayed or fails to function as the pacemaker. An accelerated junctional rhythm occurs when the junctional rate is between 61/min and 99/min and the junctional rate takes over the pacemaker function. Junctional tachycardia occurs when the junctional rate is faster than 99/min and takes over the pacemaker function.

objective.__html: Identify a junctional rhythm on ECG.

children: A 35-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for rapid heart rate and dizziness. He was recently started on levofloxacin for community-acquired pneumonia.
A telemetry rhythm strip is
shown
Which of the following abnormalities is seen on this patient's telemetry rhythm strip?

text.__html: Right bundle branch block with aberrancy

children: This patient's telemetry rhythm strip demonstrates torsades de pointes, a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. The torsades de pointes pattern is associated with QT interval prolongation and is characterized by an undulating QRS pattern that seems to twist across the baseline. This tracing also shows the initiation of ventricular tachycardia with a premature ventricular complex occurring during the repolarization phase of the previous QRS complex (“R-on-T” event). Macrolides and quinolones may prolong the QT interval, and alternative agents should be considered in patients at risk for torsades de pointes, including history of a long QT interval or use of other medications that prolong the QT interval.

objective.__html: Identify torsades de pointes on ECG.

children: A 69-year-old man undergoes screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm. Focused
ultrasonography
is performed with the probe placed just above the umbilicus.
Which of the following is the most appropriate interpretation of this study regarding an abdominal aortic aneurysm?
This patient's ultrasound
shows
an abdominal aortic aneurysm (
AAA

) with a maximal diameter of 4.8 cm, measured from outer wall to outer wall. It is important to measure the external diameter of the aorta (outer wall to outer wall) rather than the internal luminal diameter, which may underestimate aortic size if there is an intraluminal thrombus within an aneurysm. The normal diameter for the abdominal aorta is less than 3 cm; an aortic diameter of 4.8 cm, as seen in this patient, indicates the presence of an AAA. In this ultrasound, the aorta is seen in cross-section, just anterior to the vertebral bodies (
VB
), which appear hyperechoic (
white

) on the anterior surface with acoustic shadowing posteriorly. The shape of the aorta is more oval than normal, and the normal smooth lumen is replaced by an irregular jagged appearance due to the presence of an atherosclerotic plaque at the 4 o’clock position.

objective.__html: Identify abdominal aortic aneurysm using point-of-care ultrasonography.

children: A 48-year-old woman is evaluated for dyspnea associated with nausea and diaphoresis.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following abnormalities is demonstrated on this patient's ECG?

This ECG shows an acute inferior myocardial infarction, with ST-segment elevations in the inferior leads (II, III, and aVF) and reciprocal changes (ST-segment depressions) in lead aVL. There is also subtle ST elevation in leads V
through V

objective.__html: Identify an inferior myocardial infarction on ECG.

children: A 25-year-old woman is evaluated for a “racing heart” sensation.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is sinus tachycardia. This ECG demonstrates sinus tachycardia, defined as a sinus rhythm (a normal P-wave axis with an upright P wave in lead II and a constant PR interval) with a heart rate of 100/min or faster. The consistent and normal P wave morphology makes the other answer options less likely.

objective.__html: Identify sinus tachycardia on ECG.

children: A 36-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for an irregular heart rhythm. He is otherwise asymptomatic.
A representative sample from an ECG rhythm strip is
shown
Which of the following abnormalities is seen on this patient's ECG?

This ECG demonstrates Mobitz type 1 second-degree (Wenckebach) atrioventricular block, which is characterized electrocardiographically by a PR interval that progressively prolongs until, eventually, the beat is dropped. In the tracing shown, the PR interval widens over the first six beats and no ventricular complex follows the seventh atrial beat.

objective.__html: Identify Mobitz type 1 second-degree (Wenckebach) atrioventricular block on ECG.

children: A 60-year-old man is evaluated for chronic right-sided heart failure.
Chest radiographs are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is constrictive pericarditis. This
chest radiograph
shows pericardial calcification on both the posterior-anterior (
black arrow
) and lateral views (
white arrows

). Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by pericardial thickening, fibrosis, and sometimes calcification that impair diastolic filling and limit total cardiac volume. Chest radiography or CT may demonstrate partial or circumferential pericardial calcification, and CT or cardiac magnetic resonance imaging may demonstrate pericardial thickening (>3 mm). Importantly, constriction may exist in the absence of these findings.

objective.__html: Diagnose constrictive pericarditis.

children: A 23-year-old woman is evaluated for recurrent episodes of syncope. She is otherwise well and takes no medications.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This ECG demonstrates long QT syndrome. A quick way to assess whether the QT interval is prolonged is to note whether the QT interval exceeds half of the R-R interval, as is evident in this patient's ECG. The QT interval depends on heart rate; if the heart rate is between 60/min and 100/min, the corrected QT interval (QTc) is determined by dividing the actual QT interval by the square root of the R-R interval (in seconds). QTc intervals of 450 ms or less in men and 460 ms or less in women are considered normal.
Long QT syndrome can be acquired or congenital. In adults, the most common causes are drugs, including methadone, fluoroquinolones, antiarrhythmics, and psychotropics.

objective.__html: Identify long QT syndrome on ECG.

children: A 79-year-old woman is evaluated for fatigue and bradycardia.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following abnormalities is seen on this patient's ECG?

This ECG demonstrates third-degree heart block, which is characterized electrocardiographically by dissociation between the P waves and the QRS complexes. P waves discharge at their inherent rate but cannot be conducted to the ventricles. If the QRS complexes are narrow, the heart block is usually at the level of the His bundle. If the QRS complexes are wide, the heart block is lower (below the His bundle), and the rate will be between 30/min and 40/min.

objective.__html: Identify ECG features of third-degree heart block.

children: A 63-year-old man is evaluated for hypotension and orthopnea. The neck veins are examined with the patient in a semirecumbent position.
(Note that there is no sound for this
video
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient's neck examination reveals jugular venous distention, reflecting increased right atrial pressure, which is most likely caused by left-sided heart failure. Other causes of jugular venous distension include cardiac tamponade, right ventricular failure, and massive pulmonary embolism.

objective.__html: Diagnose heart failure based on jugular venous distention.

children: A 45-year-old man is evaluated for a 2-week history of subjective fever and malaise. A grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur that increases with inspiration is present at the left mid-sternal border.
A new, painful skin lesion is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is infective endocarditis. Osler nodes are tender, red-purple papulopustules located on the pulp of the digits, or occasionally on the hands or feet, which are associated with infective endocarditis (most commonly, subacute forms of endocarditis). Osler nodes are composed of microabscess and immune complex deposition in the papillary dermis, together with microemboli in the nearby dermal arterioles, and are to be contrasted with Janeway lesions, which are nontender, macular, often hemorrhagic lesions.

objective.__html: Diagnose an Osler node and understand its association with infective endocarditis.

children: An 81-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for chest pain. During the evaluation, he becomes unresponsive.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient's ECG demonstrates ventricular fibrillation. The ECG has no identifiable organized ventricular waveforms but instead shows bizarre, irregular, and random waves. Although polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (e.g., torsades de pointes) can show highly variable QRS complexes as the axis of the rhythm rotates, there is still recognizable ventricular activity.

objective.__html: Diagnose ventricular fibrillation.

children: A 31-year-old woman is evaluated for episodes of palpitations.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following abnormalities or underlying conditions is responsible for the changes on this patient's ECG?

Wolff-Parkinson-White pattern, which is characterized by QRS widening, a delta wave, and a short PR interval, is responsible for the findings on this patient's ECG. In Wolff-Parkinson-White pattern, an accessory pathway bypasses the atrioventricular node and causes preexcitation, resulting in the short PR interval and delta wave at the beginning of the QRS complex. In this ECG, positive delta waves (initial upsloping of the QRS complex) with a short PR interval are seen in leads I, II, and aVL and precordial leads V
through V

. Negative delta waves (an initial negative deflection) are seen in leads III, aVF, and aVR, giving the appearance of an inferior infarct pattern. Patients with evidence of preexcitation on their resting ECG and symptomatic supraventricular tachycardia have Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome.

objective.__html: Identify Wolff-Parkinson-White pattern on ECG.

children: A 47-year-old woman is evaluated for a heart murmur. Blood pressure is 140/70 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 60/min. Auscultation is performed with firm pressure on the diaphragm at the cardiac apex.
(We recommend listening to
this clip

with headphones or external speakers rather than internal computer or mobile phone speakers. It may be helpful to maximize the volume setting of the listening device. In the videos, a cotton swab is placed on the carotid artery to help identify the timing of cardiac sounds and murmurs and, in some cases, to provide a visual representation of the carotid artery configuration.)
Which of the following findings accounts for the auscultatory findings at the apex?
This patient has the auscultatory findings of chronic mitral regurgitation, including a high-pitched, blowing holosystolic murmur, ending with S
This murmur is loudest at the apex. The murmur of chronic mitral regurgitation classically radiates to the left axilla and left scapular area. Although not heard in this clip, an associated S
may indicate that the regurgitant flow volume is significant or that left heart failure with reduced ejection fraction has developed.

Aortic stenosis produces a harsh, systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur that is loudest at the right upper sternal edge. The murmur of mitral stenosis is heard during diastole at the cardiac apex. A pericardial friction rub may consist of one to three components and may be heard in systole, diastole, or both systole and diastole. The holosystolic murmur of tricuspid regurgitation is heard loudest at the lower left sternal edge, and the intensity may increase with inspiration.

objective.__html: Diagnose mitral regurgitation on auscultation.

children: A 51-year-old man is evaluated for syncope after prolonged standing in a warm environment.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following ECG findings is shown?

First-degree atrioventricular block is characterized by a prolonged PR interval (≥200 ms), as seen on this patient's ECG. It is usually a benign condition and does not require intervention. It is most commonly secondary to medications that slow atrioventricular node conduction, degeneration of the node, infiltrative cardiomyopathies, or, as in this case, high vagal tone.

objective.__html: Identify first-degree atrioventricular block on ECG.

children: A 65-year-old man undergoes screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm. He has a history of smoking. Focused
ultrasonography
is performed, with the probe placed just above the umbilicus.
Which of the following is the most appropriate interpretation of this study regarding an abdominal aortic aneurysm?
Abdominal aortic aneurysm is absent in this patient. The ultrasound
shows

the abdominal aorta in cross-section with a maximal diameter of 1.85 cm, with measurements taken from outer wall to outer wall. The normal maximal diameter of the abdominal aorta is 3 cm; therefore, the abdominal aorta in this ultrasound is normal in size and without evidence of aneurysmal dilation. The aorta (
Ao
) is positioned just anterior to the vertebral bodies (
VB
), which appear hyperechoic (
white
) on the anterior surface with acoustic shadowing posteriorly. The aorta appears round, smooth, and anechoic (
black

objective.__html: Identify abdominal aortic aneurysm using point-of-care ultrasonography.

children: A 57-year-old woman with peripheral artery disease is evaluated prior to elective cholecystectomy.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely electrocardiographic diagnosis?

This ECG demonstrates left posterior fascicular block, which occurs when conduction system disease involves the posterior fascicle of the left bundle branch. It is defined as a pathologic right axis (>+90 degrees) with no other cause (such as right ventricular hypertrophy). The QRS duration is less than 120 ms with a negative QRS complex (small R wave and deep S wave) in leads I and aVL and a qR pattern in leads III and aVF. Left anterior fascicular block is recognized by a positive QRS complex in lead I and a negative QRS complex in lead aVF. Right bundle branch conduction disturbance combined with anterior or posterior left bundle branch block is called bifascicular block.

objective.__html: Identify ECG features of left posterior fascicular block.

children: A 52-year-old woman is evaluated for exertional dyspnea and orthopnea. Blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 60/min. Auscultation over the apical impulse is performed with light pressure on the bell.
(We recommend listening to
this clip

with headphones or external speakers rather than internal computer or mobile phone speakers. It may be helpful to maximize the volume setting of the listening device. In the videos, a cotton swab is placed on the carotid artery to help identify the timing of cardiac sounds and murmurs and, in some cases, to provide a visual representation of the carotid artery configuration.)
Which of the following best describes the acoustic events at the apex?
The acoustic events at the apex are best described as S
+ S
+ S
. An S
is heard in this patient. An S
is a low-frequency, early diastolic sound best heard with the bell of the stethoscope at the cardiac apex. It may be perceived as a double S
. Positioning the patient in the left lateral decubitus position will facilitate the identification of an S
. An S
is often heard in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction but can also be present in volume overload states, such as valvular regurgitation, shunt lesions, or late pregnancy. An S
can also represent a normal finding in children or highly trained athletes.
An S
is also a low-frequency diastolic sound, but it occurs in late diastole and thus may be perceived as a double S
Both components of a split S
are high-frequency sounds heard best with the diaphragm in the second left intercostal space. Splitting of the S
represents asynchronous closure of the aortic and pulmonic valves. In the normal adult, splitting varies with the respiratory cycle and is perceived as a single S
during expiration and a double S
during inspiration. Paradoxical splitting of S
is characterized by audible splitting during expiration and a single S
during inspiration. It is often associated with aortic stenosis but does not differentiate mild from severe aortic stenosis.

objective.__html: Identify an S<sub>3</sub>.

children: A 65-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-week history of persistent fatigue and occasional exertional dyspnea.
ECG is
shown
Which of the following abnormalities best describes the findings on this patient's ECG?
This ECG shows a completed lateral myocardial infarction, with initial deep Q waves in leads I, aVL, and V
. There is also an inverted T wave in these leads.

objective.__html: Identify a completed lateral myocardial infarction on ECG.

children: A 77-year-old man is evaluated for a 10-day history of fever and fatigue. Two years ago, he underwent dual-chamber pacemaker implantation. He reports tenderness at the site of his pacemaker, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is device-associated infection. The image depicts device erosion through the skin. Device-associated infections have many different forms, ranging from pocket infections to endocarditis. Most infections are caused by
Staphylococcus epidermidis
and
Staphylococcus aureus

. Symptoms of cardiac device infection include fever, chills, malaise, lassitude, and failure to thrive. Physical examination of the pocket may reveal erythema, swelling, drainage, wound dehiscence, or device erosion.

objective.__html: Diagnose device-associated infection.
